title: co.combinatorics - Conjugation of bosonic and fermionic
body: We use the notation from semi-infinite wedge formalism $\bigwedge^{\infty/2}V$ with vector space $V$ generated by $$\left\{\underline{s}\mid s \in \mathbb{Z}+\frac12\right\}$$ , we consider the charge zero subpsace where $v_{\lambda}$ from the basis for partition $\lambda$ . $\psi$ is the fermionic operator and $\psi^{*}$ is conjugate. $:\psi_{k-n}\psi_{k}^{*}:$ is normal ordering. We have the following operators on the charge zero subpace. $$\mathcal{E}_{n}(z):= \sum_{k\in \mathbb{Z}+\frac12}\exp(z-\mu /2):\psi_{k-n}\psi_{k}^{*}: $$ $$\mathcal{F}_n := \sum_{k\in \mathbb{Z}+\frac12}\frac{k^n}{n!}:\psi_{k-n}\psi_{k}^{*}: $$ $$\alpha_n := \mathcal{E}_n (0)$$ Let $p_{r}(\lambda):=\sum_{i=1}^{\infty} (\lambda_i -i+\frac12)^r-(-i+\frac12)^r $ which are eigen value of $\mathcal{F}_r$ For $r=2$ It can be shown that $$\exp({s\mathcal{F}_2})\alpha_{-n}\exp({-s\mathcal{F}_2})= \mathcal{E}_{-n}(-ns) $$ what will be the conjugation for $$\exp({s\mathcal{F}_r})\alpha_{-n}\exp({-s\mathcal{F}_r})= ? $$ in terms of $\mathcal{E}_n$ ?
